The young and the friendless: Loneliness when young

19/06/2022

Hannah Carley explains how today's youth can be just as, if not more, lonely than their elders

Image by TomÃ© Louro

By Hannah Carley

This week is Loneliness Awareness Week, an annual campaign to raise awareness of the struggles of the lonely. Launched by the Marmalade Trust in 2017, it aims to shine a light on and get people talking about loneliness and reduce the stigma experienced by those suffering from it. It is an important time in which we should consider those we care about who may not necessarily feel cared for, seen or understood.

Naturally, its existence also helps to publicise the huge range of amazing individuals and organisations that do work to support those experiencing loneliness or social exclusion. Groups like Age UK, Mind, and Meet Up Mondays all work to alleviate the pain and mental strain that comes from isolated living. Their work is undeniably invaluable, and this time of year does a great job to publicise it and offer recognition.

Loneliness in old age is a particularly well known issue, with loneliness affecting over one million older adults in the UK. Over half of people aged 75 or older live alone, and the deterioration in physical health that is typical of this age group can make participating in the community or socialising with others increasingly challenging. For those without family or regular visitors, isolation is easily further compounded. Research even shows that feeling lonely can worsen existing health problems such as chronic pain. Numerous organisations specialise in offering social and communication based activities to elderly members of the community, such as Uni of Yorkâ€™s own Tea and Coffee Club, where volunteers spend time with elderly local residents in a relaxed setting each week, offering a hot drink, biscuits and companionship.

From this stems society's typical stereotype of the lonely â€“ an older person who lives alone with no family, has few to no visitors and probably doesn't get out much. Think of those sad Christmas adverts with the pensioner alone in a dark house on Christmas Day. And as weâ€™ve seen, a lot of lonely people do unfortunately fit this description. Yet this is just that â€“ a stereotype. Many do not consider the impacts that loneliness can have on those outside of this age group, and in particular, the ways in which feeling isolated can resonate with young people.

40 percent of people aged 16 -24 report feeling lonely often or very often. The narratives of society forget that younger people and even children can and do feel this way, and as such support and understanding for those that need it is often undervalued or not recognised as needed by those around them. This perception not only increases the fears and stigma surrounding the natural phenomenon of ageing, but also hinders the finding of solutions for loneliness for all.

We assume that itâ€™s difficult for young people to be lonely. They are at school, university, are going out and are surrounded by people. But this doesnâ€™t mean that you are immune from isolation or that you definitely fit in. We undeniably live in a society where the pressures and strains on the younger population are particularly high. Ever increasing prices, exam pressures and an increasingly competitive job market only make things more tenuous, and yet the expectations on youth from other corners of society remain the same, if not higher.

In education settings, these risks can be even more profound, with many students in schools and beyond facing issues making friends and fitting in, particularly those from minority backgrounds. Even then it is easy for students to feel isolated within their friendship groups. In busy settings such as education establishments, it is easy to feel out of place within a group, ignored or misrepresented, and in schools where popularity and cliques often rule this is easily further exasperated. University appears to be a particular flashpoint for loneliness â€“ with almost half of students admitting to feeling lonely at some point during their degree.

The impacts of loneliness on the young are potentially as dangerous as it itself is profound. Young people go through numerous periods of transition during their lives and any such transition has a huge impact on our sense of self. Feeling a strong sense of belonging or a connection to others can help us to reaffirm and establish our identities through these changes, helping us to settle in and thrive in our environments. On the lonely, this is lost. Loneliness has also been found to be one of the leading predictors of mental distress amongst university students. In a time where the mental health of those of all ages has been especially tested, this social issue can have undeniable impacts on the physical health and mental wellbeing of our friends and loved ones, not to mention ourselves.

Itâ€™s an experience I personally understand all too well, and that followed me all through my education until university. I struggled to make friends for most of my time at school. At the inner city academy I attended, my nerdiness and interest in learning was not seen as very cool and as a result, I got picked on for the things that made me different. I was very much a social outcast. This came to a head during Year 7, where I was bullied by a group of boys for most of the year. It was a difficult time and I felt like I had no one to turn to. Thankfully my form tutor eventually became aware of what was going on and was quick to support me and stop my tormentors.

The effects were long lasting though â€“ I had few friends and still to this day lack confidence in a lot of social situations. It was a bad start to my time at a new school and even when things got better, they werenâ€™t great. Even when I found my people later on in my school career I lacked close friends and confidants, and often did not have people I felt I could talk to about the things going on in my life. Feelings of isolation and inadequacy crept in. It made the hard times harder and left some of the good times tainted. Failing exams, losing loved ones, questioning and then accepting my sexuality; loneliness made everything more difficult. I wasnâ€™t necessarily alone, wasnâ€™t always without friends ,but I was almost always lonely â€“ and to this day that period still has an effect on me.

For me, university was a game changer. Perhaps the first time I was able to find my people and connect with others who had been through similar experiences to me. Societies and liberation groups â€“ not to mention my amazing friends (you know who you are) â€“ allowed me to feel truly accepted and present. Although, most of them still donâ€™t understand my obsession with motorsport. Nevertheless, Iâ€™m now in a much better place and have felt comfortable enough to begin working on myself. It was a long time coming, though.

But for many, their years at university can be the loneliest of their lives. Not all of us make friends in freshers week or are lucky enough to find a student group or two where they feel truly at home. Living alone for the first time, perhaps hours (or oceans) away from family, means that university is a sink or swim time when it comes to social integration. And, unfortunately, a fair few of us will drown.

So what is being done about this? And what can we do as individuals?

Well, groups up and down the country are beginning to notice the ways in which isolation can affect young people. Services such as Samaritans are also there to support you if you are feeling isolated as well as services specific to York like York Nightline, and the array of student Â and liberation groups on campus that will behappy to listen and support you if you so need it. Approaching them can be as easy as picking up the phone, or in the case of Nightline, perhaps sending a quick email. At York in particular we are lucky to also have a college system full of amazing staff whose job it is to support students with any struggles they have with transitioning to university life. Students and staff at York are (mostly!) really nice and will more than likely be happy to offer you a helping hand.

More and more is being done to understand and support children,teenagers and young adults who find themselves in positions like mine, higher education included and with hindsight I can attest for how positive a change it really is.

There is also so much we can do ourselves to support others if we are worried that they are left out. Being aware of loneliness also means understanding the ways our own actions can cause others to be lonely. Don't single people out. If you see someone standing to the side of a conversation bring them in. Learn about the perspectives and struggles of minority groups and consider how you can make spaces safer and more inclusive for people from them. It takes all of us to make social interaction and community building easy and safe, and this can make it so much easier for someone to pursue a less lonely lifestyle.If you are particularly interested and able, you can volunteer with organisations like those weâ€™ve discussed to help those suffering to find community or maybe just vocalise their struggles and concerns.

It is also important to not just actively include others, but also to consider what you are involving them in â€“ maybe donâ€™t invite your particularly introverted friend to a social where they are unlikely to know anyone already, for instance. Help people to break out of their comfort zone, but do it in a sustainable, supportive and realistic way. Most of all, don't pressure anybody into scenarios where they aren't comfortable. Not only is it a common courtesy but it avoids the situation where someone is overwhelmed, socially retreats and loneliness stagnates or worsens. Most of all, just be there and be present for those around you that need it, whether they know they need it or not.

Itâ€™s obvious that loneliness must not continue to be seen as exclusively a problem for the old. But this requires all of us to rethink our attitudes and perceptions towards not just age, but our social norms. We need to make it so that admitting you didnâ€™t have many friends growing up is not something shocking or taboo, or the stories I can tell of my experiences will remain all too common. Isolation is not abnormal, but merely a circumstance. It can befall on all of us. Each of us needs to know how to support others â€“ and ourselves â€“ when it is, regardless of how far back our date of birth may be.
